intro: Verticordia grandis, commonly known as the Hairy Wattle, is a striking member of the Proteaceae family native to Western Australia. It is characterized by its bright yellow flowers, which are clustered in dense, cylindrical inflorescences. The plant typically grows in sandy or gravelly soils and is often found in heathland and woodland environments. Its foliage consists of narrow, leathery leaves that are covered in fine hairs, giving it a distinctive appearance. Verticordia grandis is a hardy, drought-tolerant species that thrives in full sun and is popular in native gardens.
